subject: Add retry for recoverable PKCS11 errors
commit_message:
Add retry for recoverable PKCS11 errors

When using the p11_crypto module with an HSM, certain errors can be thrown by
the device that currently require the Barbican application to be restarted to
recover. This CR adds to work already done to the pkcs11 module that will trap
known errors and will raise a specific exception that can be handled gracefully
without the need to restart the entire application.

In addition, the p11_crypto module has been enhanced to use a retry mechanism
when these known errors are raised after reinitializing the pkcs11 library.
This was done specifically to trap the CKR_TOKEN_NOT_PRESENT error from an HSM,
but can be enhanced further in the future to handle additional error conditions
that are recoverable with a simple reinitialization of the library to prevent
the need to restart the entire Barbican application.

Change-Id: Ic43f3729bff00560d4a344f785416546c019e016
Closes-Bug: 1582884

commit_message:
Add transport_url parameters for oslo.messaging

This commit adds the transport_url parameters for oslo.messaging. The url is
of the form:

  transport::/user:pass@host:port/virtual_host

Where the transport scheme specifies the rpc or notification backend as one of
rabbit, amqp, zmq, etc. Oslo.messaging is deprecating the host, port and
auth configuration options [1]. All drivers will get these options via the
transport_url.

This patch:
* use oslo::messaging::default resource
* use olso::messaging::notifications resource
* add new parameters for transport_url(s)
* update spec tests for added parameters
* add feature release not

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/317285/

LXC cache have mismatches, the 'apt-get upgrade' and/or
'apt-get install' actions can fail due to dpkg asking what to
do about the config file mismatches.

keep the existing in-place file (the file copied from the
host). This ensures that whatever apt configuration was
implemented on the host is definitely used in the containers.

subject: Add option to choose partition alignment mode
commit_message:
Add option to choose partition alignment mode

Under certain circumstances due to that alignment, the end of
particular partition could cross 1M boundary. And due to actual
partition' bounderies being rounded up, fuel-agent mistakenly
assumes that partition couldn't fit within provided boundaries
and raises errors.WrongPartitionSchemeError.

However, some h/w data storages are well known for reporting
relatively huge optimal IO sizes (16M or even bigger), so the 1M
room can't be enough. Thus, optimal aligning is not an option.
In such cases, it's better to proceed with minimal mode.

It's the minimum aligment needed to align the partition properly
to physical blocks which avoids performance degradation.

subject: Add [pci] group and whitelist_sections to configure PCI passthrough
commit_message:
Add [pci] group and whitelist_sections to configure PCI passthrough

The current pci_passthrough_whitelist option using embedded json
causes issues for devstack [1].

This proposes a new section [pci] with a config variable
'whitelist_sections' that lists a number of individual sections to
describe the same PCI-passthrough options.  For example, two
white-lists might be defined as:

 [pci]
 whitelist_sections = pci_rule_foo, pci_rule_bar

 [pci_rule_foo]
 product_id = 1520
 vendor_id = 8086

 [pci_rule_bar]
 vendor_id = 1137
 product_id = 0071
 address = *:0a:00.*
 physical_network = physnet1

Note that we enforce the subsections having the "pci_rule_*" prefix to
avoid potential for namespace issues later.

This modifies class WhiteList() to take both the json strings from
pci_passthrough_whitelist and dictionaries created from
whitelist_sections.  Test-cases are updated to exercise the new
argument.

Use of pci_passthrough_whitelist will give a warning message about
it's deprecation, but both methods can co-exist.

[1] http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-dev/2014-October/049341.html

subject: WIP: libvirt storage pools initial step
commit_message:
WIP: libvirt storage pools initial step

This code has never been executed. It undoubtedly contains not only
logical errors, but also syntax errors. Tests haven't been touched at
all, except by automated refactoring. Don't bother looking at the
changes to the tests: they're meaningless.

This change introduces StoragePolicy as a replacement interface for
Backend. There are a few reasons for this change. Firstly, it starts
to centralise code which assumes the placement of disks. This makes
the existing behaviour simpler to follow. Note that this change
attempts to be minimally functional, simply to centralise the existing
behaviour. Sometimes that behaviour doesn't make much sense, for
example the shared storage detection, but we have at least centralised
the problem.

Secondly, we have a goal of changing this placement in moving to
libvirt storage pools. The StoragePolicy interface gives us a hook to
make that change. I anticipate that StoragePolicy will become
LegacyStoragePolicy and will remain in place. We can then use a hook
on storage_policy_for_instance() to select the correct policy for an
existing instance, and to run an upgrade if required.

This change makes 1 slightly less mechanical non-functional change:
Image.import_file -> Image.import_local_file.  This allowed me to
remove an if block on default image type, as well as being more
readable.

This change makes one functional change out of expediency: snapshot
was the only code using disk paths from the libvirt xml rather than
inferring them from nova state. Although the libvirt xml is a source
of absolute truth, if it doesn't correspond to expectations we're
already broken. Rather than maintain 2 very different interfaces, I
have consolidated to using nova state. If this is wrong, it was going
to break somewhere else anyway. It is also simpler to validate.

Going from here, we need to split Image into StoragePool and
StorageVolume. Operations like cache() and create_image() are
operations on the pool. Operations like libvirt_info, resize, and
snapshot_extract are operations on a volume. The StoragePolicy will
create singletons for each pool, and pools will create volumes.

We can then implement new StoragePools which use libvirt, and a new
StoragePolicy which returns them.

StoragePool needs a cleanup_for_instance() method.

N.B. ImageCacheManager is not recoverable. It assumes on-disk layout
everywhere. It is extremely hard to follow. It is extremely hard to
validate. Its structure and code flow are undesirable. It will
continue to manage the 'legacy' storage pools, but the new storage
pools will be managed by a new image cache manager, which will require
a new periodic task.

subject: Refactor hostname resolution via DNS
commit_message:
Refactor hostname resolution via DNS

Due to oddities in the way that DNS used to work on older MAAS
versions, specifically when using LXC containers, the charm
would endeavour to discover a full forward/reverse resolvable
hostname/ip address to use when clustering with peers, and to
set the internal nodename for each RMQ instance.

Changes in MAAS 2.0 mean that an IP address may resolve to more
than 1 DNS record, making identification via DNS of the FQDN
problematic.

The charm actively manages /etc/hosts with IP address/hostname for
all peer units in a RMQ cluster using the cluster relation; make
use of this feature to allow the internal nodename of each unit
to actually be the hostname of the server, as the charm is ensuring
the resolvability of hostnames within the cluster.

To avoid races where the lead unit has not had its hostname written
to /etc/hosts, only cluster with the lead unit in the hook execution
where this actually happens.

subject: Refactor puppe-openstack-integration jobs
commit_message:
Refactor puppe-openstack-integration jobs

TL;DR, here's what we want:

openstack/puppet-openstack-integration to run:
* check:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
  - all puppet4 scenarios, non-voting
* gate:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
* experimental:
  - puppet3 + puppet4 + all scenarios on Xenial
* periodic:
  - drop puppet4 jobs (move them to check)

openstack/puppet-* modules to run:
* check:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
* gate:
  - all puppet3 scenarios, voting (no change)
* experimental:
  - all puppet4 scenarios, non-voting
  - puppet3 + puppet4 + all scenarios on Xenial

Long version:

Previously, we used to run puppet4 jobs in experimental AND periodic
pipelines.

We noticed that puppet4 jobs are breaking quite often and periodic jobs
are not enough for us since we don't have any notification to let us
know of failures. Indeed, the jobs appear in
http://status.openstack.org/openstack-health/#/ but only when Tempest
runs. Most of the failures don't reach Tempest run and fail before.

We think that we should start running puppet4 jobs in our check
pipeline, and we chose puppet-openstack-integration as a first
iteration, since this project does not have a lot of commits.

This patch does:

In Jenkins:
* Modify puppet-openstack-integration job-template:
  - stop using {pipeline} since everything will be in gate.
  - add {job-suffix} so we can use '-nv' later.
* Add '-nv' suffix to:
  - Xenial Puppet 3 job (we consider it experimental).
  - All Puppet 4 jobs.
* Do not use '-nv' jobs for those that we consider voting (puppet3 jobs
  on trusty & centos7).

In Zuul layout:
* Create puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-check-nv with all puppet4 jobs
  Note: we didn't add puppet3 job on Xenial because we want to keep it
  experimental (non-voting and run on demand) for now.
* Execute puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-check-nv jobs in
  puppet-openstack-integration project (not much commits per day, so
  won't consume a lot of resources).
* Create puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-exp-nv with the same jobs
  as puppet-openstack-integration-jobs-all-check-nv but using
  experimental pipeline. These jobs will be created for Puppet modules
  CI so we can check them at demand.
* Add '-nv' suffix to all jobs that we consider non-voting, experimental
  or not.

commit_message:
Cells: Decrement available slots

On build, decrement a cell's available ram slots. Using the scheduler_count
configuration option the available capacity per cell is effectively divided
per scheduler. This prevents multiple schedulers from flooding the same cell

each of the smaller slots reported (e.g. a build request for a 2048 slot

subject: Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore
commit_message:
Instead of a multiprocessing queue use sockets via asyncore

For a local process based executor usage currently to ensure
that task emitted notifications are proxied we use the multi
processing library and use its queue concept. This sadly creates
a proxy process that gets associated, and this proxy process
handles the queue and messages sent to and from it. Instead of
doing this we can instead just create a temporary local socket
using a random socket and have tasks (which are running in
different processes) use that to communicate back any emitted
notifications instead (and we can use the asyncore module to handle
the emitted notifications since it handles the lower level socket
reading, polling and dispatching).

To ensure that the socket created is somewhat secure we use a
similar process as the multi-processing library uses where we
sign all messages with a hmac that uses a one time key that only
the main process and the child process know about (and reject
any messages that do not validate using this key).

subject: Fix keepalived functional tests
commit_message:
Fix keepalived functional tests

Running the tests locally I'm seeing:
http://paste.openstack.org/show/493222/

The issue in all three tests is that the keepalived manager
process spawns asynchronously (sudo -> root_helper -> keepalived).

For the 'spawns' test, it was asserting that process.alive was
True when it should have used wait_until_true.

For the respawns* tests, the test grabs process.pid before the process
has necessarily spawned. Moving process.pid to after the wait_until_true(
process.active) loop guarantees that pid will return keepalived's
process. Otherwise the 'pid' variable will be None, then when we
use utils.execute we try to kill the 'None' pid, and that doesn't seem
to work.

subject: Add a best-effort sudo safety check
commit_message:
Add a best-effort sudo safety check

As motivation for this; we have had two breakouts of dib in recent
memory.  One was a failure to unmount through symlinks in the core
code (I335316019ef948758392b03e91f9869102a472b9) and the other was
removing host keys on the build-system
(Ib01d71ff9415a0ae04d963f6e380aab9ac2260ce).

For the most part, dib runs unprivileged.  Bits of the core code are
hopefully well tested (modulo bugs like the first one!).  We give free
reign inside the chroot (although there is still some potential there
for adverse external affects via bind mounts).  Where we could be a
bit safer (and could have prevented at least the second of these
breakouts) is with some better checking that the "sudo" calls
*outside* the chroot at least looked sane.

This adds a basic check that we're using chroot or image paths when
calling sudo in those parts of elements that run *outside* the chroot.
Various files are updated to accomodate this check; mostly by just
ignoring it for existing code (I have not audited these calls).

Nobody is pretending this type of checking makes dib magically safe,
or removes the issues with it needing to do things as root during the
build.  But this can help find egregious errors like the key removal.

subject: Wait for at least one suitable disk to appear on start up
commit_message:
Wait for at least one suitable disk to appear on start up

Some kernel modules take substantial time to initialize. For example,
with mpt2sas RAID driver inspection and deployment randomly fail
due to IPA starting before the driver finishes initialization.

This problem is probably impossible to solve in a generic case, as
modern Linux environment do not have a notion of "hardware is fully
initialized" moment. All hardware is essentially hotplug.

To solve it at least for the simplest case, this patch adds a wait loop
on start up waiting for at least one suitable disk to appear in inventory.
Note that root device hints are not considered, as the node might not
be known at that moment yet.
